question.title: What does it mean that the Jakarta EE Platform specification adds support for a specific Java SE runtime?
question.body:
The Jakarta EE Platform 10 specification states the following:

The goal of the Jakarta EE 10 release is [...] adding the support for the Java SE 11 and newer runtimes. The TCKs require support for both Java SE 11 and Java SE 17.

What does this mean? Specifially, I'm wondering what this means regarding the Java SE version

  • in terms of Java SE features used in the Jakarta EE Platform 10 specification (i.e., does it mean that the APIs specified in the specification can only use features which are compatible with both Java SE 11 and Java SE 17)?
  • in terms of Java SE features being available for implementing the Jakarta EE Platform 10 specification (i.e., features of which Java SE version can vendors of application servers use?)
  • required to run an application server which implements the Jakarta EE Platform 10 specification
  • in terms of Java SE features being available for implementing applications which are deployed in an application server which implements the Jakarta EE Platform 10

I guess my understanding in how all of this relates is lacking - it would be great if you could shed some light on this!

answers.body:
tl;dr

A customer deploying an implementation of any Jakarta EE 10 technology must be able to install it on their computers running either Java 11 or Java 17.

Details

The goal of the Jakarta EE 10 release is [...] adding the support for the Java SE 11 and newer runtimes

Jakarta EE is a collection of dozens of technologies generally of interest to enterprise-oriented developers. Those technologies consist mainly of (1) a specification, and (2) some Java code that defines an API made up mainly of interfaces (and abstract classes, perhaps, with possibly some incidental concrete classes).

Every Jakarta EE technology is expected to be run on a JDK, an implementation of the Java specifications.

Java 11

Third parties implement those Jakarta EE interfaces with concrete classes while following the Jakarta EE specifications. To comply with the specs for Jakarta EE 10, the authors of an implementation cannot use new Java features introduced after Java 11.

For example, an implementation cannot use Java records, as that feature arrived in Java 16. An implementation using records would fail to run on a customer’s computer equipped with Java 11. Such an implementation would not be Jakarta EE 10 compliant.

Java 17

And the Jakarta EE 10 specification also requires compliance tests be run on both Java 11 and Java 17. To quote:

The TCKs require support for both Java SE 11 and Java SE 17.

That means an implementation cannot use any features that were removed from Java 17 or from earlier versions of Java.

For example, the java.util.jar.Pack200 class was removed in Java 14. Any implementation calling that class will fail to run on Java 17. Such an implementation would not be Jakarta EE 10 compliant.

Questions

in terms of Java SE features used in the Jakarta EE Platform 10 specification (i.e., does it mean that the APIs specified in the specification can only use features which are compatible with both Java SE 11 and Java SE 17)?

A compliant implementation of Jakarta EE 10 must run on both Java 11 and Java 17. A customer deploying an implementation must be able to install on their computers running Java 11 or Java 17.

  • An implementation using features not present in Java 11 would be non-compliant.
  • An implementation using features removed by Java 17 would be non-compliant.

in terms of Java SE features being available for implementing the Jakarta EE Platform 10 specification (i.e., features of which Java SE version can vendors of application servers use?)

An implementation of a Jakarta EE 10 technology can use any Java feature present in both Java 11 and 17.

required to run an application server which implements the Jakarta EE Platform 10 specification

Any app server product claiming to implement any Jakarta EE 10 technology must be able to run on both Java 11 and Java 17.

in terms of Java SE features being available for implementing applications which are deployed in an application server which implements the Jakarta EE Platform 10

You can write an app using Jakarta EE 10 in any version of Java you want. For example, your app written in the current version Java 24 will likely run well if deployed on Java 24. However, knowing that Jakarta EE 10 implementations are tested specifically on Java 11 and Java 17, the most conservative approach would be to develop and deploy using either Java 11 or Java 17 only.

You may choose to test your app occasionally with the latest version of Java to guard against inadvertently writing code that is not future-ready. Likewise, you may want to occasionally test with a later implementation of Jakarta EE to ensure your app remains future-ready.

Tip: Make a habit of studying the Release Notes for Java and for Jakarta EE upon every release. Stay apprised of changes that may affect your app in future migrations.

LTS

Why Java 11 and Java 17 specifically? These are Long-Term Support (LTS) versions of Java, along with versions 8, 21, and likely 25.

Know that the Jakarta EE project has intentions to eventually peg major releases around six months after a Java LTS version release. Currently, Java LTS releases arrive every two years in the autumn.

It basically means that in order to be a compliant Jakarta EE 10 container you need to pass the TCK on at least Java SE 11. An implementation can choose a higher version of Java SE to compile against, but it's unlikely they would do so.

The Jakarta EE 10 specification API's are all compiled to Java SE 11 bytecode. Whether or not the implementations of the specification work on newer versions of the Java SE is up to the implementation. However, in most cases I think you will find they work fine on newer versions of Java SE.

I don't really follow the questions on Java SE features. If the minimal runtime is Java SE 11, you can assume you're allowed to use most Java SE 11 features. One caveat would likely be JPMS, but that's likely not an issue in most environments.

You're really mostly limited on the what version of Java SE you run your application server on.

question_comments.body: Lets go old. Jakarta EE is the rebranded name of the old Java EE, The Java EE platform is built on top of the Java SE platform. The Java EE platform provides an API and runtime environment for developing and running large-scale, multi-tiered, scalable, reliable, and secure network applications. The Jakarta EE 10 release is built on the Java SE 11 platform. Does that clarify things?

79644650.body: @nistel It just means that the TCK needs to be able to be executed on Java SE 11 and Java SE 17.

If the sentence "The TCKs require support for both Java SE 11 and Java SE 17." doesn't mean that the "implementation must pass on Java SE 11 and Java SE 17" (that's what I thought so far), what does it mean then?

The specifications are compiled to Java SE 11 bytecode because they need to run on Java SE 11. The implementation can choose the version of Java SE it requires. See jakarta.ee/specifications/platform/10/…. I'm not sure I follow the other part of the question. You can compile down to Java 11 bytecode and still run on Java SE 17+.

2) Yeah, but what is the reason for that? Is it, such that the JDK for Java SE 11 can also run the application server? Because, if it was compiled to Java SE 17 bytecode a JDK for Java SE 11 maybe might not be able to run the application server? 1) I understand that there isn't anything special about Jakarta EE, but the answer to my question should still be "yes", shouldn't it? Because otherwise, how could both JDKs for Java SE 11 und 17 be able to start the application server and the behaviour being the same?
The quote from the specification literally says that the TCKs also require support for Java SE 17. Why do say then that it is enough to passt the TCKs for Java SE 11? What am I missing here?

1) It's as compatible as running any Java SE 11 bytecode on Java SE17. There is nothing special about it being Jakarta EE.  2) It may be written down somewhere, but I know it to be true. Specification API's are compiled to the lowest version required by the Platform specification.   3) For a lot of the API's there are multiple implementations. For example RESTEasy and Jersery for Jakarta REST or Hibernate and EclipseLink for Jakarta Persistence. There is no requirement on the projects that they compile to SE 11. However, most if not all do.
The TCK's need to run against Java SE 11 as a minimum because that is the minimum the platform requires.

"The Jakarta EE 10 specification API's are all compiled to Java SE 11 bytecode." I have three questions regaring this: 1) Does this mean that the result of running Java SE 11 bytecode of specification APIs with a Java SE 11 JDK is identical to running it with a Java SE 17 JDK? 2) Is this specified somewhere or is this just a logical necessity in order for both Java SE 11 und Java SE 17 JDKs to be able start an application server supporting both Java SE 11 und 17? 3) I'm wondering why you only mentioned the API - wouldn't this be true for the implementation of the API then, too?

"It basically means that in order to be a compliant Jakarta EE 10 container you need to pass the TCK on at least Java SE 11. " Why is enough to pass the TCK Java SE 11? As quoted in the question from the specification: "The TCKs require support for both Java SE 11 and Java SE 17."

79644965.body: @BasilBourque Jakarta EE 11 phrases it the same way: "The TCKs require support for both Java SE 17 and Java SE 21." (jakarta.ee/specifications/platform/11/…). Glassfish 8.0.0-M14 claims that it is "implementing Jakarta EE" though "JDK 21 is required as a minimum" for the final release (note: JDK 17 seems to work in principle, too, but "JDK 17 is not longer available, these builds were only intended for TCK purposes.") (github.com/eclipse-ee4j/glassfish/releases/tag/8.0.0-M14) - wouldn't this somehow support what James R. Perkin says?

They do say the TCK's require support for Java SE 11 and Java SE 17, it doesn't say that an implementation must pass on Java SE 11 and Java SE 17. See jakarta.ee/specifications/platform/10/… "This specification requires that containers support execution in a Java™ runtime environment, as defined by the Java Platform, Standard Edition specification, v11 or later (Java SE 11 or later)."

@jamesrperkins The Jakarta EE 10 spec says: “The TCKs require support for both Java SE 11 and Java SE 17.”. If you don’t support both Java 11 and 17, you don’t pass the TCKs. If you don’t pass the TCKs, you’re not compliant.
This isn't quite right. Implementations can require Java SE 17 and still be considered compliant. The minimum of Java SE 11 just means you cannot go below that version.
